instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00923: What is 820-00923? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.USBC_XA_CC2: What is USBC_XA_CC2? USBC_XA_CC2 is a line between the USB-C muxing chip such as the CD3217 or CD3215 and the USB-C charger. Communication must happen on this line in order for the USB-C charger to put out 20v..
definitions.USBC_XB_CC1: What is USBC_XB_CC1? USBC_XB_CC1 is a line between the USB-C muxing chip such as the CD3217 or CD3215 and the USB-C charger. Communication must happen on this line in order for the USB-C charger to put out 20v..
definitions.USBC_XB_CC2: What is USBC_XB_CC2? USBC_XB_CC2 is a line between the USB-C muxing chip such as the CD3217 or CD3215 and the USB-C charger. Communication must happen on this line in order for the USB-C charger to put out 20v..
definitions.USBC_TB_CC2: What is USBC_TB_CC2? USBC_TB_CC2 is a line between the USB-C muxing chip such as the CD3217 or CD3215 and the USB-C charger. Communication must happen on this line in order for the USB-C charger to put out 20v..
definitions.CD3214: What is CD3214? This is a common typo,  the person typing CD3214 was most likely referring to CD3215.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no activity on ampmeter
threads.message:
Hi there,

after some time of inactivity i'm back :) 
I got some problem with an MBP 2017 4TBT here. 
It doesn't show any signs of liquid damage but was obvisously opened before.
First step was checking amp and voltage with ampeter but there the charger does not even turn the ampmeter on - on all 4 ports. 
I aready tried a known good charger and a known good USB-C Connector.

I would be very thankfull for some ideas wha could be the problem here.

Thank you

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no activity on ampmeter
threads.message:
First check input fuses; F3000/1 and FB200/1.
Next check diode mode to ground on CC1/2 pins of all <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips.
Remove USB-C connectors and inspect their terminals for corrosion.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no activity on ampmeter

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no activity on ampmeter
threads.message:
Seems that all chips are bad.
Did you inspect USB-C terminals?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no activity on ampmeter
threads.message:
Yes, all terminals ae looking good - no corrosion or dust or any damage. 
So I should start replacing the <CHIP>CD3214</CHIP> Chips...?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no activity on ampmeter
threads.message: Remove one and check if short/low ressitance disappear from its corresponding CC1/2 lines.
